rice: Prefer clayey loam soils with good water retention; transplant or direct-seed depending on local practice.
Maintain standing water during early vegetative stages and ensure drainage before harvest.
Apply nitrogen in split doses (basal + top-dress); follow soil test for P and K.
Use disease-resistant varieties when available and monitor for blast and sheath blight.
maize: Plant in well-drained fertile soils and full sunlight; avoid waterlogging.
Apply higher nitrogen during vegetative growth and potassium during grain filling.
Follow recommended spacing (e.g., 60 x 20–30 cm) and remove weeds early.
Scout for stem borers and fall armyworm; apply IPM measures as needed.
wheat: Cool-season crop; sow during recommended window for your region.
Use well-drained loamy soils; avoid high temperatures during grain fill.
Use split nitrogen applications and monitor for rust diseases.
Rotate with non-host crops to reduce disease pressure.
chickpea: Inoculate seed with Rhizobium for better nitrogen fixation.
Apply phosphorus at sowing; conserve moisture during flowering.
Manage pod borer with monitoring and local IPM practices.
kidneybeans: Grow on loamy, well-drained soils with neutral to slightly acidic pH.
Ensure adequate phosphorus at planting; moderate nitrogen only if needed.
Keep fields weed-free early and irrigate evenly; avoid waterlogging.
Harvest when pods are mature and dry quickly to avoid mold.
pigeonpeas: Tolerant of dry conditions; best on deep, well-drained soils.
Minimal N required if well-nodulated; use recommended spacing.
Prune/maintain canopy for air circulation to reduce foliar diseases.
Use IPM for pod borers and consider early planting to escape pests.
mothbeans: Suitable for light, sandy soils and arid conditions; drought tolerant.
Plant shallow; low fertilizer requirement—focus on soil organic matter.
Use as ground cover to reduce erosion; monitor for pod-sucking insects.
mungbean: Short-duration crop; plant in warm weather with well-drained soils.
Inoculate seeds with Rhizobium to improve nitrogen fixation.
Keep weed pressure low during early growth; harvest timely to prevent losses.
Rotate with cereals to improve soil health.
blackgram: Grows on light to medium soils; prefers warm climate.
Seed inoculation with Rhizobium improves yields.
Avoid excessive nitrogen; apply P and K as per soil test.
Monitor for foliar diseases and use resistant varieties if available.
lentil: Cool-season legume; prefers well-drained loamy soils.
Inoculate with Rhizobium and apply phosphorus at sowing if deficient.
Avoid waterlogging; rotate to reduce root rot risk.
Harvest at physiological maturity and dry properly.
pomegranate: Thrives in deep, well-drained soils; avoid waterlogging.
Irrigate regularly during fruit development; reduce before harvest for better sweetness.
Prune to open canopy; fertilize based on leaf analysis.
Monitor for fruit borers and fungal diseases; use local recommendations for sprays.
banana: Prefer deep, fertile soils with good organic matter and regular moisture.
High potassium requirement—apply as per soil/leaf analysis.
Use clean planting material to avoid viral diseases and practice sanitation.
Support plants if necessary and remove diseased material promptly.
mango: Well-drained soils and full sun; protect young trees from wind.
Apply balanced fertilizer timed to flush cycles; potassium for fruit quality.
Prune for canopy management and thin fruits for size and quality.
Manage anthracnose and powdery mildew with good cultural practices and sprays.
grapes: Require well-drained soils and trellis systems for training.
Prune annually to control yield and improve quality.
Manage powdery mildew and botrytis with canopy control and targeted fungicides.
Irrigate carefully—steady moisture is better than extremes.
watermelon: Warm-season crop; prefers sandy loam and full sun.
Provide consistent moisture during fruit set; reduce irrigation before harvest for sweetness.
Use drip irrigation and plastic mulch to conserve moisture and reduce pests.
Rotate crops and monitor for bacterial fruit blotch and insect pests.
muskmelon: Similar to watermelon; needs warm days and cool nights for best flavor.
Use well-drained beds and mulch; ensure adequate potassium for sweetness.
Harvest at optimum maturity (fragrance/slip) for best quality.
Protect from fruit flies and practice sanitation.
apple: Temperate climates; choose cultivars and rootstocks suited to local chill hours.
Maintain soil fertility and practise regular pruning and training.
Thin fruits to improve size and reduce biennial bearing.
Monitor for codling moth and scab; use integrated pest management.
orange: Deep, well-drained soils and full sun; steady irrigation for fruit enlargement.
Apply balanced NPK and micronutrients based on leaf analysis.
Protect from citrus greening by using certified planting material and monitoring.
Prune lightly and manage irrigation to avoid water stress.
papaya: Quick-growing; prefers well-drained fertile soils and warm temperatures.
Plant with adequate spacing and protect young plants from wind.
Provide regular irrigation and organic manure; monitor for fruit flies.
Use disease-free planting material to avoid viral diseases.
coconut: Thrives in sandy, well-drained soils with high sunlight and humidity.
Mulch and irrigate during dry periods; maintain soil organic matter.
Apply potassium and micronutrients for nut quality.
Control rhinoceros beetle and bud rot with sanitation and recommended measures.
coffee: Grows under shade; prefer well-drained fertile soils and regular organic matter.
Prune to manage tree architecture and improve yields.
Monitor for coffee leaf rust and berry borer; use resistant varieties and IPM.
Proper post-harvest drying is crucial for quality.
cotton: Warm-season crop on well-drained loamy soils; good tilth helps root growth.
Split nitrogen applications improve fiber quality; follow soil test recommendations.
Monitor for bollworms and aphids; use IPM and Bt hybrids where suitable.
Timely irrigation during boll development improves yield.
jute: Grows well in alluvial soils with adequate moisture; avoid waterlogging at harvest.
Sow at recommended densities and apply P and K for fibre quality.
Harvest at the right retting stage for good fibre extraction.
Rotate and use healthy seedlings to reduce disease incidence.
default: Follow local variety and sowing-time recommendations for the best results.
Base fertilizer applications on a soil test and maintain soil organic matter.
Monitor regularly for pests and diseases and adopt integrated pest management.
